RT @AdamScochran: Jake breaks down an important shift we‚Äôre seeing in the token space with a rapid expansion of new asset types and how we‚Ä¶

Are we sensing yet the magnitude of @aantonop‚Äôs prediction?

My Token Proliferation Thesis is that we‚Äôll see millions of new ERC20s in the next year 1-2 years. 

/end

Projects like @AragonProject and @FairmintCO are taking crowdfunding into the token dimension as well.

The addressable market for digital organizations is, in principle, more than all companies.

But just in startups, there are 100m launched each year!

https://t.co/fZWCXfryxi

The are 1.2m subreddits with ‚Äúonly‚Äù 138,000 subreddits being active. Reddit however has over 430M monthly active users, dwarfing Bitcoin users by several factors.

Meanwhile, @AdamScochran defines community tokens *as its own wholesale asset class*:

https://t.co/ipWzgZLTt5

Online communities have long been natural candidates for ‚Äúlocal currency‚Äù, membership tokens, or reputation. Now, one of the largest online communities is heading for integration.\n\nhttps://t.co/aHQkdUPvk7

As more physical goods go online in digital form, marketplaces like @ourzora are becoming emitters of ERC20 as well. 

Here, Zora debuts a rap album denominated by a new token called $TAPE. Albums have sold for over $800 using this mechanism. 

https://t.co/MnLVkK0YLV
In particular, creators in the #cryptoart scene have launched a number of #artcoins allowing holders to engage and purchase works.\n\nhttps://t.co/4Gphkab4Ka

The UIs for wholesale token creation have advanced dramatically. 

Both @tryroll and @meTokens are just two examples of apps where individuals can create and manage #SocialCurrency.

The addressable market for such tokens is ~4.5B people.

Here‚Äôs mine! https://t.co/qagTx90YpU

In principle, any wrapper token can be insured by cryptonative insurance or options, as demonstrated by @opyn_.\n\nNaturally, selling cryptonative insurance contracts creates more tokens, such as Opyn‚Äôs #oETH. https://t.co/aJV0kIxqZP

Perhaps it started with #DeFi.\n\nUser friendly interfaces popped up for creating many new ERC20 compatible smart contracts, like @UniswapProtocol pools. Every protocol with deposits could now also issue wrapper tokens to users, pioneered by #cTokens at @compoundfinance.

Almost the entire time since 2015, issuing tokens required deployment of smart contracts to Ethereum. \n\nBut by 2020, we are seeing the market align toward a mass proliferation of tokens: there are now both more reasons for tokens and more friendly mechanisms for creating them...
Around the time of Andreas‚Äô talk, (I estimate) there were hundreds or thousands of #ERC20 tokens deployed on #Ethereum.\n\nToday that number stands at at least 262,535.

Here is @aantonop‚Äôs talk, still extremely insightful many years later. Needless to say this view was not popular in the core #bitcoin community in 2015 and remains unpopular today. \n\nhttps://t.co/ARcTcyr0Eb

Thread! üëáüëá

‚ÄúTo ask how many currencies will exist is to ask how many bloggers there will be on the Internet. The answer is simple: all of us. Currency is now a means of expression.‚Äù

5 years ago @aantonop posited millions of currencies.

What can we say about this view today?

‚ÄúBlockchain: there‚Äôs a politically decentralized, strongly private, censorship-resistant, automated, efficient zero-margin open source dApp for that!‚Äù\n\nAnd you can also co-own and govern it if you want. . .

‚Äúsubredditizing‚Äù media organizations into smaller units of specialized content.

We must have better access and verification of sources.

Users must self-select channels, not be firehosed by data.

Big Media and Big Tech as substrate have to go.

Hyper fast information flow is a terribly polarizing force for the general public.

Media was once used to keep people informed, today it is used to direct one‚Äôs attention to the appropriate political channels to which one is susceptible.

Really sad to see. May be mitigants.

In general, we should prefer projects that employ the value props of blockchains: mainly open coordination.

But in particular, we should prioritize projects that achieve optima cryptoeconomically.

Like @ethereumJoseph explained long ago, that sets us up for exponential growth.

If economic systems can be compared, the space of such systems have optima; cryptoeconomic systems can achieve the optima quickly.\n\nFor example, if a stimulus optimum is that each citizen receives $1200, that system can be achieved in a tiny amount of code.

What are the value propositions of blockchains?

Last time I counted, I found about 12. They are mainly shades of open coordination.

One interesting one: that these networks are cryptoeconomic, meaning +/- that their economics can be designed as software.

@TahiGichigi @antiprosynth Point being, you cannot implement Facebook on Ethereum, you need a dedicated network. And the same is true across the flavors of other use cases at scale.\n\nSo, to me, saying "the biggest network takes all use cases" is a nonstarter.

@TahiGichigi @antiprosynth Well, you missed my original point is that not all base layers can handle every kind of app.\n\nTake Facebook. Facebook works on a special high scale graph database. Facebook can only work with such an architecture. And ONLY Facebook needs that architecture to work.
@TahiGichigi @antiprosynth Almost nothing, long term, for simple applications. And almost infinity for complex ones with a lot of deep requirements.
From an asset picking perspective, it doesn‚Äôt make sense to talk about ‚Äúwhich base layer will win‚Äù, only about which zones/assets will capture the most value for the investor.

e.g. Polkadot consists of many parachains in a single zone whose value is captured by $DOTs.\n\nApp-dedicated chains will capture value for a single application which can grow larger than some base layers.
Value-capturing investments don‚Äôt compete across a substrate of base layers.\n\nValue-capturing investments compete across zones where a some asset captures the value of the activities in the zone.

7/Things get really interesting when you extend this concept of "risk intermediary for NFTs" to *all* NFTs. But I'll save those details for another tweetstorm. ;)\n\n/end

6/...we can tokenize this risk! At a high level, imagine a #DAO which pools the capital of its token holders in order to purchase and resell NFTs. ü§î

One example:

https://t.co/3DIzrBDVb5

5/What if we could find another group of people who were willing to take on the risk of holding these illiquid assets after the creators create them, but before the long-term holders hold them?\n\nIn the old world, this meant finding an art patron or investors, but in blockchain...

4/Sell-siders (creators) risk their time and effort to make works they think they can sell. Without a strong buy-side, they take most of the risk. How can we bootstrap this two-sided market?\n\nBasically by sustaining the sell-side long enough for the strong buy-side to form.

3/But the underlying issue is about lacking a buy-side. 

Buy-siders in the NFT world are art whales, collectors, & speculators -- they take on the risk of owning a nonfungible because they think they can sell it later, or just because they like it.

https://t.co/XYBG9ZE9j5

2/Projects and creators are looking at the market and asking themselves how they might be able to make NFTs more liquid.

Approaches include auctions, fractionalizing ownership and listing the ERC20 token on an exchange, using NFTs as collateral, etc.

https://t.co/sQD9xKJ08P

1/A quick thread on where I see #NFT space going in the next little while.

tl;dr I think #cryptoart and #collectibles will become more liquid, inevitably with the help of a risk-diversifying cryptoeconomic mechanism -- DAOs.

- Finally we got to the NFT minting stage. I sent my newbie some ETH to get them set up, and they were able to see it on @zerion_io via @rariblecom and make their first work.\n\n@etherscan was a bit too technical, but Zerion seemed just right.

- I had a lot of explaining to do. What does it mean to "mint an NFT"? What's Ethereum? What's an Ethereum address? How much is 0.3 ETH?  I showed the newbie some of the other accounts and how they could see the whole NFT world on @opensea.\n\nOpenSea helpfully supported Fortmatic!

- I realized the most straightforward onboarding would be via a hosted wallet like @fortmatic, and I needed a platform where they could just go and mint NFTs. Since each of the top platforms currently require artist approval, I went with @rariblecom instead.

- After that failed, I considered setting them up with @argentHQ and then picking an NFT platform which supported @WalletConnect. Unfortunately, that would require two devices (iPad + iPhone) and two setups which seemed complicated.

Implications:

- You can now price an #artcoin relative to how the market values that artist‚Äôs work.

- Better liquidity for all artists.

- Price of the token doesn‚Äôt depend on the artist‚Äôs actions directly, but on which works are immutably pegged to this token.

- A simple approach is to peg an NFT to the #cryptoartist‚Äôs #artcoin, like $HUE or $GOU or others from @tryrollhq have done.

- Then put (or issue) the #artcoin on a bonding curve.

- What we very simply achieve using basic primitives is a bonding curve liquidity for #cryptoart.

On the other hand, the team staking increases the quorum and quota required to pass a vote, making it harder to pass.

Proof is simple: the onus is *always* on the Yea-voters to meet the quota, rather than the Nay-voters to overrule Yea-voters. If Yea-voters succeed, Nay-voters are powerless to overrule since quota is 50%. If Yea-voters fail, then it wasn't because team abstained.
One thing that @yiryan and I learned from studying the @DigixDAO voting system is that the team staking the vote and then "abstaining from voting" is equivalent to voting "No".

@azeroz You have this covered, as in, you have a protocol with such properties? If so, I would be very interested to explore it.

Here's why this is hard: to earn nonnegative fiat-denominated returns without market risk, you need a stable asset. But most stable assets we know about inherently carry massive counterparty or market risk on the backend.\n\nThoughts, cryptotwitter?

The killer cryptoeconomics is a financial protocol where both of the following hold:

- Users can earn nonnegative fiat-denominated returns in exchange for liquidity.

- The user's risk is predominantly technical or systemic risk, but not counterparty or market risk.

Governance tokens are an interesting counterexample in many token valuation scenarios. 

What are your thoughts?

/end

At the beginning of the game, we valued each token at $1. But once we got into the scenario, Dave and Carol might have valued each token at $101. Simultaneously the market might value Alice and Bob‚Äôs tokens at $0, expecting the treasury to be emptied. And so on.

Overall, there is a lot to consider in this simple scenario.\n\nOne important consequence I walk away with is that when it comes to governance tokens, at times their valuation might subjectively vary and units might become non-fungible.

Multiple folks in the thread pointed out that it might be impossible to know exactly what other ‚Äúout of band‚Äù economics are happening between Dave and Carol, and even the other players. This opens the game up for possible manipulation on-chain.
In Ultimatum Game experiments, studies have shown that as the overall magnitude of the reward increases, players tend to transact even if the split is unfair.

Dave is a buyer in this scenario, but it‚Äôs not clear if Carol has other buyers. If so, then stating that ‚Äúyou have 5 seconds to decide whether you want to pay me $176 and walk away with $25, or I go to the next buyer‚Äù might be an effective tactic for Carol.

We might be able to factor in Carol‚Äôs costs‚Äîfor instance, if voting is going to require gas fees on Ethereum. Costs on both sides simply push the profitability window between Carol and Dave closer together.

The cost of capital might skew the price in Dave‚Äôs favor, since the capital burden is on him. If it costs Dave $5 in interest or opportunity cost to pony up capital, he might argue for a $5 improvement in his price.

Carol might argue that Dave should pay as much as $200.99, or he gets nothing. In the same way, Dave might counterargue that Carol should accept $1.01 or get nothing.\n\nIn the absence of additional information, this seems to motivate an even split to help them transact.

Some folks have suggested that splitting the revenue here is a form of Ultimatum Game. As such, giving an even split to both Carol and Dave might create an appealing option.\n\nIn this case, Dave pays $101 for 1 token, and both players walk away with $100 profit.

If the payment P to Carol is somewhere between $1 and $201, then both Dave and Carol make money. That concludes the quantitative analysis.\n\nThe subsequent analysis is understanding where on that spectrum are behaviorally interesting values of P and why.

Now suppose your network sets inflation as a function of revenue. Then the features are no longer independent (though still tractable), and requires a much more complex model that convolutes features.
These features are independent and it‚Äôs relatively straightforward to propose valuations: account for inflation with a discount factor, account for future cash flows with DCF.
An example. Suppose you have a token with two features: the token supply receives the revenue of the network uniformly, and the token supply inflates at a fixed rate.

Just sat at a productive symposium discussing approaches to cryptoasset valuation frameworks.

One takeaway: an infinitely complex design space engenders infinitely complex models.

So issuers should keep their models simple and the features of those models independent.

In Japanese 6-seaters, labeling goes KJH, CBA which makes perfect sense.

Window seats on the right get labeling preference, hence A.

But painfully missing from our discourse of reform is technological literacy and digital thinking.\n\n/fin

We are still super early in the development of technologies that will fundamentally overturn our economic operating systems and change the landscape of labor and capital. \n\nThese reforms will take much time and development, and we should be realistic about that.

The traditional assumption that worker‚Äôs economics and industrial profits are in a zero-sum game will also be smashed, as sustainable social structures like insurance, basic income, and financial services are also provided by networks, not employers or governments.
Decentralization technology will do more than any other reform to align the interests of human labor and the economic structures that consume it and are capable of exploiting it.

Social media, computation, cloud services, value transfer, and digital marketplaces and many other goods will be operated by efficient public networks whose governance will be owned by their users and workers. Eventually physical marketplaces and manufacturing will follow.

Using decentralized networks, the world will eventually unravel the conglomerate into its constituent goods. Those goods which are public commodities ‚Äî like, as we now realize, social media is ‚Äî will no longer be driven (and exploited) by the Firm.

Many processes (freelancing, startups, impact investing) drive toward more empowered workers and smaller corporations, but few offer a more effective toolset than decentralization tech. The best part of this eventual transition is that its achieved through competition, not gov‚Äôt.
Instead, we should be looking for technologically-advanced ways to empower the freelancer with benefits, insurance, and time-flexibility while decentralizing and shrinking the roles of Uber and Lyft.

If you take this view, then reform that, for example, ‚Äúrepatriates‚Äù ridesharing drivers as employees into their parent companies is actually regressive. It solves the problem of employee benefits, but reinforces the unsustainable corporate operating system status quo.

Yet, as the piece notes, we are already in a process of consolidation of large corporations and heading to a breaking point. One way or another ‚Äî through automation, anti-trust, and decentralization ‚Äî we will enter a regime where economic agents are smaller and more specialized.

A union is technology that attempts to level the playing field between a large economically-powerful agent and a consortium of smaller economically-weak agents; and so it rests on the assumption that such large players are immutable and pervasive. (Surely true today.)
We now have enough technology, in principle, such that this no longer need be the case.

The digital domain creates efficiency, transparency, speed, and feedback loops for processes that traditionally required large, concerted, monolothic, and hierarchically-organized coordination ‚Äî like the industrial-era corporation ‚Äî in order to be orchestrated.

...and the economic operating systems upon which they are built and iterated.

Corporations, governments, workers, and unions are analog technologies created through a natural evolution and analog thinking.

We now rapidly enter a digital domain, which requires digital thinking.

Reading pieces like ‚ÄúState of the Unions‚Äù, I hope we update our inertial reactive thinking about worker reform, which frames it in a seemingly immutable context of corporations. \n\nIn fact, the greatest reform eventually comes from the reformulation of the corporation itself... https://t.co/HBkB4Hw9qh

However, @fredwilson is also correct in saying that "scaling problems abound" because blockchain scalability is by no means an easy feat and a challenging tech problem. \n\nThis is an active space with constantly changing problems, solutions, and new breakthroughs.

Finally, when @Nouriel testifies to Congress that "blockchains don't scale", he's clearly (again to your point) not "up to speed" on sidechain technologies like #zkrollups, @maticnetwork, or even @Hyperledger-based @PropsProject which is serving a mass use case in prod today.

First, current throughput across major blockchains is definitely enough to handle the demand of the present moment.\n\nSecond, short-term progress in state channel technologies is essentially ready to take on demand for fast transfer use cases on top of Ethereum and other L1s.

I am grateful to be pitted against @fredwilson in the scalability debate in your article, but as you point out yourself nuance abounds.\n\nMy take that "blockchain is scalable in the foreseeable future" comes from a very practical understanding of current demand and current tech.

@koeppelmann @econoar There‚Äôs also a bias: the things built on Ethereum by definition are limited to the design space of such things, which is finite modulo the expressable architectures.\n\nThat means a platform whose design space can express other architectures will be serving different use cases.
@koeppelmann @econoar The use cases that will be demanded by the market are unknown. So it‚Äôs hard to postulate whether Ethereum‚Äôs architecture could or couldn‚Äôt support them.
@koeppelmann @econoar It‚Äôs not clear that we couldn‚Äôt have an offchain network that used an Ethereum based set of incentives to implement this.\n\nBut as you can see, it‚Äôs a lot of nuance.

@econoar I agree Ethereum will integrate other tech. But I also know (and see that) a single architecture cannot serve all use cases.\n\nSo either the applications of Ethereum are not as wide as we think, or it will interoperate with other architectures that will serve other use cases.

@_RJTodd It‚Äôs tough. We may not have those metrics. They may not be calculable easily (or sensibly) across funds.\n\nHumbly I suggest the valuable analysis here would be of nuances of how the indices can be misleading; Bitcoin outperforming on absolute % is not interesting nor insightful.

Finally, a shoutout to @VisionHill_ for doing a really hard job: compiling and standardizing really stubborn data across a large number of fund strategies that are complex to compare. \n\nCc: @danzuller @scottarmy_ @Melt_Dem @mdudas

As the indices show, the #cryptofund space has professionalized a bit and matured into different strategies (quant, fundamental, etc.). To have $BTC as a benchmark makes less sense in this context: the reasons for holding $BTC or a quant fund interest might be very different.

Moreover, many funds in the #cryptofund space hold illiquid assets, often at cost. The returns of those investments are only apparent in annualized retrospect and of course do not get a chance to weigh in on this real-time analysis.

Of course this headline, while true, does not take into consideration risk-adjusted returns. \n\nYou can make more $BTC absolute returns versus a diversified vehicle. 8/Just another fascinating case of lending protocol rates interacting with other #CryptoeconomicSystems. Will lending rates be explained by factor models in payment and staking systems? We‚Äôll find out shortly. /fin

7/We‚Äôre talking a potential addressable market of $8.8b of throughput needed in state channel hubs annually just on these metrics of our small community, while @compoundfinance has $146m in supply. \n\nhttps://t.co/XAOOr4ol04

6/To put things into more concrete terms, I was surprised or learn that the median Ether transaction today was about $500. And that doesn‚Äôt even include token values. And if you look at wallets, some of the most successful ones have done as many as 1.5m transactions per month.

5/In this scenario, fees might not converge to 0 but instead to the lending rate of the assets needed to capitalize the network (or a well-behaved function of them). That‚Äôs pretty unusual in my theoretical explorations.

4/This is potentially a really interesting result in #DeFi. In most networks, we are used to thinking that provider competition erodes fees to 0 (a race to the bottom)! \n\nBut crypto payments is prospectively a huge market which requires *a lot* of capitalization for hubs.

3/Instead of locking capital, hub operators might leverage lending protocols to borrow it & increase throughput. However, the borrowing rate will inform the commission hubs will charge (and vice versa).
2/#Layer2 is coming and in these networks we must capitalize state channel hubs in order to create throughput. This creates a substantial hurdle for running hubs & caps commissions.

1/I think we will find in retrospect that decentralized lending protocols and their lending rates are of universal importance not just to #DeFi, but to the entire ecosystem.

‚ÄúCryptonetworks will challenge infrastructure monopo‚Ä¶
@G7685502036 Do they get subsidy?
Do such models exist? How would incumbents react to these shifts in the market? Will Amazon itself have incentives to join the network?\n\nWe‚Äôll have to watch in real time. /end

So that‚Äôs really the hurdle: can we come up with a token economics that can channel enough subsidy to the network for it to exceed the difference between the incumbent‚Äôs and network‚Äôs costs?\n\nIf so, Amazon better watch out. https://t.co/HLffHZQokb

. . .they can still theoretically operate on a ‚Äúsynthetic margin‚Äù created by the token value. This of course requires a feasible token model that reasonably, fundamentally captures the value of the network. \n\nThat‚Äôs not easy, but we do see a few good candidate models today.

The second mechanism is a lot more interesting. The network might use a token economics in order to subsidize network participants. So even though their *costs* would be higher than Amazon‚Äôs, and their *margins* would erode to 0 through network competition. . .

The first mechanism is by crowdsourcing resources ‚Äî like cloud storage ‚Äî from global participants. The trick is that because this storage is already paid for, decentralized networks (at least temporarily) might be able to lower costs of service provision below the incumbent‚Äôs.

By definition, these networks of providers cannot achieve *greater economies of scale* than huge incumbents. \n\nHowever, there are at least two mechanisms by which networks *might* still achieve *cheaper pricing* which, given enough time, can put entire Amazons out of business.

What they coordinate on is competing with incumbents on weak points: closedness, privacy, censorship-resistance, customer experience, and of course pricing.\n\nThey also compete with each other, eroding their margins to nearly 0. (More on that later.)

We tend to think of networks as monolithic protocols that compete with a large incumbents like Amazon as a unit. \n\nBut of course such networks are also coalitions of small-to-medium providers that have agreed to follow the network‚Äôs rules in order to coordinate.

I am working on a post about decentralized resource networks (think file storage or computation) competing with the unit economics of large, efficient incumbents (think Amazon).\n\nWow, when you write this stuff out on paper, things get very interesting.üëá

Thank your local dex arbitrageur when you see them for making your trading experience better at great risk.

On the other hand, dex traders enjoy:

1. A low regulation environment (they need all the slack they can get).

2. Today, really inefficient markets and large spreads.
In 60 seconds, the liquidity of a centralized exchange can shift multiple percentage points against an on-chain arbitrageur.

In many ways, it‚Äôs amazing that on-chain order books operate at all.

1. Dexes must have arb to support pricing on dexes.

2. Those folks incur insane risks: must pay gas to even replace orders, wait up to minutes to execute.

3. Resulting costs of on-chain arb is very high.

4/That said, consortia are also a decentralization mechanism. Decentralization sometimes can lower risk by distributing the responsibility of a common enterprise across consortium members. Consortia can also build powerful distribution networks for their products.
3/So as the consortium puts a dent into the business of members, the long-term return starts to look less attractive.

2/For members, the mutual business of the consortium must create a higher long-term return potential than that of short-term competition. Yet, a successful long-term consortium share will ultimately earn less than a successful monopoly on that business.

1/In my experience & observation, private consortia are *really hard*. When the business of the consortium actually starts impacting that of members, the consortium incentive becomes much less attractive.
